Gurley (20) pumped during warmups at Williams-Brice Stadium in Columbia on Saturday, September 26, 2015. (Photo: MYKAL McELDOWNEY/Staff) Buy Photo 10 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
COLUMBIA – In Head Ball Coach fashion, Steve Spurrier walked into Tuesday’s press conference alongside USC President Harris Pastides, Athletics Director Ray Tanner and Gamecocks interim coach Shawn Elliott with a brisk pace. 
“Let’s get this thing over with,” Spurrier said as he headed to the dais. 
Spurrier addressed his reasons for deciding to step down as the Gamecocks coach, but refused to use the dreaded “retired” word. 
“I’ll have something planned,” said Spurrier. “Everyone has told me, once you sort of give up your day job, you need to have something planned to do. I’ll have something planned to do. 
“I don’t know what, yet, though.” 
With that Spurrier ended a Hall of Fame coaching career that some believe puts him on the Mount Rushmore of Southeastern Conference Coaches. 
Following three consecutive 11-2 finishes, with the last leading to a ranking of fourth nationally, Spurrier was deeply disappointed with the Gamecocks 7-6 mark last season. 
He was so disappointed that he contemplated walking away and did just that briefly. 
Tanner was able to talk Spurrier into returning, however. 
Despite appearing re-energized, he could not shake questions about his retirement. 
That, along with the team’s poor start, proved more than Spurrier could bear. 
That led to a call to Tanner on Sunday and an announcement to upperclassmen on his team that it was time to walk away. 
“There comes a time when you’ve just got to ask what direction is our football is going,” said Spurrier. “It wasn’t going the way we hoped so I need to step aside.” 
While it is believed USC, led by Tanner will conduct a national search for its next coach, Elliott is not giving up the belief he can help the Gamecocks turn their season around and put himself in the mix. 
A Camden native, Elliott grew up a South Carolina fan and attended many games in Williams-Brice Stadium. 
When Spurrier was looking for an offensive line coach, Elliott actively recruited The Head Ball Coach, promising if he hired him, he wouldn’t regret it. 
After interviewing several USC assistant coaches Monday night, Tanner talked to team captains Pharoh Cooper, Mike Matulis, Isaiah Johnson and Skai Moore. 
Spurrier opted not to indorse any of his assistants, leaving that decision to Tanner. 
He then called Elliott and offered him the interim head coach position. 
“I want to thank coach Spurrier,” said Elliott. “Six years ago he took a chance on me and brought me here to Carolina.” 
Elliott hopes to hit the ground running as he says job one is preparing for Vanderbilt on Saturday. 
Elliott is credited with introducing the “Zone Read” concept to the Gamecocks offensive attack. 
It was particularly successful during Connor Shaw’s tenure as quarterback and appears suited to freshman Lorenzo Nunez’s talents. 
Elliott could also bring an energy that has been lacking in the program. 
He will probably fine-tune the offensive attack to even more suit his way of thinking. 
Elliott has promoted quarterbacks coach G.A. Mangus to offensive coordinator, while Fountain Inn native and former Hillcrest and USC standout Travelle Wharton has been promoted to offensive line coach. 
He had an 11-year career in the National Football League with all but one spent with the Carolina Panthers. 
Other than finding a way to defeat Vanderbilt, job one for Elliott is finding a way to boost recruiting which has fallen on hard times in recent years. 
Since the exit of homegrown Palmetto State players Marcus Lattimore, Jadeveon Clowney, Stephon Gilmore, D.J. Swearinger and DeVonte Holloman, there hasn’t been the same level of talent in South Carolina. 
The Gamecocks coaching staff have not been able to compensate by getting highly regarded talent from out of state. 
While there are exceptions, the majority of players USC has lured out of the talent rich state of Georgia have been those left over after the Bulldogs, Alabama, Auburn and others have taken what they wanted. 
Considered one of USC’s best recruiters, Elliott will work hard to start that process. 
"When I walked in this morning, I said to our staff our goal is to win this week,” said Elliott. “Win today. Win tomorrow, Win the next day and beat Vanderbilt. 
“Our team is not in shambles as some might say. We’ve got a great group of energetic young men who are ready to go out there and lay it on the line.” 
With the Gamecocks owning a 2-4 overall and 0-4 SEC mark, Elliott has a job on his hands. 
If he finds a way to turn things around, he will become a serious candidate to keep the position. 
If not, Tanner is prepared to search nationwide for what he believes is the right person to return the program to where Spurrier had it at its height and then go beyond.
